title: Research Paper Drafting — Organizing Sources and Creating an Outline
description: Students learn to organize research findings into a structured outline for a multi-paragraph research paper. They practice categorizing information from multiple sources, creating topic sentences, and planning the logical flow of their argument.
instructions:
1. Review the purpose of a research paper: inform and persuade with evidence.
2. Discuss organizing research notes by subtopic.
3. Model creating an outline from categorized notes.
4. Introduce outline structure: Roman numerals, letters, numbers.
5. Practice writing topic sentences for each main section.
6. Discuss transitions between sections.
7. Model integrating evidence from multiple sources into one paragraph.
8. Introduce in-text citations: giving credit to sources.
9. Students create detailed outlines for their research papers.
10. Peer review outlines for logical flow and completeness.

slides.heading: Research Paper Drafting
slides.subheading: Organizing Sources and Creating an Outline

slides.setup_instructions: Distribute outline templates and citation guides. Ensure students have their research notes organized by subtopic.

slides.text: A research paper is built on organization. Before writing a single sentence, you need a blueprint: your OUTLINE. Group your research notes by subtopic. Each subtopic becomes a section of your paper. Arrange sections in logical order: chronological, cause-effect, or most-to-least important.

Outline format: I. Introduction (hook, background, thesis). II. First main point (topic sentence, evidence, analysis). III. Second main point. IV. Third main point. V. Counterargument and rebuttal. VI. Conclusion (restate thesis, summarize, final thought). Under each Roman numeral, use letters (A, B, C) for supporting details.

Each body paragraph needs a TOPIC SENTENCE that states the paragraph's main idea. Then EVIDENCE from your research supports it. Then YOUR ANALYSIS explains why the evidence matters. This is the TEA pattern: Topic, Evidence, Analysis. Never let evidence speak for itself — always explain its significance.

IN-TEXT CITATIONS give credit to your sources. When you use information from a source, note the author and year: (Smith, 2020). Direct quotes need page numbers: (Smith, 2020, p. 42). Citing sources is not just academic honesty — it strengthens your paper by showing your claims are backed by experts.

slides.prompt: Build your research paper outline: (1) Sort your research notes into 3-4 subtopic categories. (2) Arrange subtopics in logical order. (3) Write a topic sentence for each section. (4) Under each topic sentence, list 2-3 pieces of evidence with source citations. (5) Note where you will address a counterargument. (6) Draft your thesis statement. (7) Exchange outlines with a partner: Is the logic clear? Are there gaps in evidence? Does the order make sense?

slides.text: An outline is like a map for your paper — it shows you where you are going before you start the journey. Time spent planning saves time writing and produces a stronger paper. Your outline ensures every paragraph has a purpose and every claim has evidence.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student organize research notes into a logical outline, write effective topic sentences, plan evidence integration with citations, and structure a multi-paragraph argument?

parent_notes: Research paper writing is a multi-week process that develops critical thinking, organization, and academic writing skills. The outline stage is crucial — a good outline makes drafting much easier. Help your child by asking about their topic and outline structure. If they can explain their paper's organization verbally, they are ready to write. The citation practice builds academic integrity habits early.

title: Ratios in Action — Scaling Recipes and Solving Proportions
description: Students explore ratios as a way to compare two quantities. They learn to write ratios in three forms, simplify ratios, and apply ratio reasoning to real-world situations including recipes, maps, and mixtures.
instructions:
1. Define ratio: a comparison of two quantities.
2. Show three ways to write ratios: 3:4, 3 to 4, 3/4.
3. Practice identifying ratios in everyday situations.
4. Simplify ratios using the GCF (connect to earlier learning).
5. Distinguish between part-to-part and part-to-whole ratios.
6. Solve ratio problems: If the ratio of boys to girls is 3:5, and there are 15 girls...
7. Apply ratios to recipes: scaling up and down.
8. Connect ratios to fractions and division.
9. Students solve a variety of ratio application problems.
10. Reflect: Where do you see ratios in daily life?

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare colored counters for hands-on ratio exploration. Print recipe scaling worksheets and ratio problem sets.

slides.text: A RATIO compares two quantities. If a class has 12 boys and 16 girls, the ratio of boys to girls is 12:16, which simplifies to 3:4. Three ways to write it: 3:4, 3 to 4, or 3/4. ORDER MATTERS: 3:4 (boys to girls) is different from 4:3 (girls to boys). Always specify what you are comparing.

Simplify ratios the same way you simplify fractions — divide both parts by the GCF. Ratio 18:24: GCF is 6, so 18:24 = 3:4. PART-TO-PART ratio compares one group to another: boys to girls = 3:4. PART-TO-WHOLE ratio compares one group to the total: boys to total students = 3:7 (since 3+4=7).

Ratio reasoning: If boys to girls = 3:5 and there are 15 girls, how many boys? The ratio tells us for every 5 girls there are 3 boys. 15 girls = 3 groups of 5. So boys = 3 groups of 3 = 9 boys. You can also use equivalent ratios: 3:5 = ?:15. Since 5 x 3 = 15, multiply 3 x 3 = 9.

Recipes are perfect ratio examples. A cookie recipe for 24 cookies uses 2 cups flour and 1 cup sugar (ratio 2:1). For 48 cookies (double), use 4 cups flour and 2 cups sugar. For 12 cookies (half), use 1 cup flour and 1/2 cup sugar. Scaling recipes is ratio reasoning in action.

slides.prompt: Ratio practice: (1) Write the ratio of red to blue counters in three forms and simplify. (2) In a bag of 30 marbles, the ratio of green to red is 2:3. How many of each color? (3) A recipe for 8 pancakes uses 2 cups mix and 1.5 cups milk. Scale it for 20 pancakes. (4) On a map, 1 cm represents 50 km. Two cities are 7.5 cm apart. How far apart are they? (5) A paint mixture uses red and blue in a 5:3 ratio. If you need 40 total cups, how many cups of each color?

slides.text: Ratios are everywhere: recipes, maps, sports statistics, financial comparisons, and scientific measurements. Understanding ratios prepares you for proportions, percentages, and rates — some of the most practical mathematics you will ever learn.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student write and simplify ratios, distinguish part-to-part from part-to-whole ratios, solve ratio problems using equivalent ratios, and apply ratio reasoning to real-world contexts?

parent_notes: Ratios are among the most practical math concepts. Involve your child in cooking (scaling recipes), shopping (comparing prices per unit), and sports (batting averages, win-loss ratios). The connection to GCF and fractions reinforces earlier learning. If your child grasps ratios well, they are building a strong foundation for proportional reasoning, which is the gateway to algebra.

title: The Age of Exploration Continued — Columbian Exchange and Its Consequences
description: Students examine the Columbian Exchange — the transfer of plants, animals, diseases, and ideas between the Old and New Worlds after 1492. They analyze both the benefits and devastating consequences, including the impact on Indigenous populations.
instructions:
1. Review the Age of Exploration: motivations and key explorers.
2. Define the Columbian Exchange: global transfer after Columbus's voyages.
3. Map what traveled from Americas to Europe: tomatoes, potatoes, corn, chocolate, tobacco.
4. Map what traveled from Europe to Americas: wheat, horses, cattle, sugarcane, diseases.
5. Discuss the population catastrophe: European diseases and Indigenous peoples.
6. Analyze how new crops transformed global diets and economies.
7. Discuss the forced labor systems that emerged: encomienda, slavery.
8. Examine multiple perspectives: European, Indigenous, African.
9. Students create Columbian Exchange maps and impact analyses.
10. Reflect: Should we celebrate or critique the Age of Exploration?

slides.setup_instructions: Print Columbian Exchange diagrams and blank world maps. Select age-appropriate primary source excerpts from multiple perspectives.

slides.text: After 1492, the Old World (Europe, Asia, Africa) and New World (the Americas) exchanged plants, animals, diseases, and ideas on a massive scale. This COLUMBIAN EXCHANGE reshaped every continent. From the Americas came tomatoes, potatoes, corn, chocolate, vanilla, tobacco, and turkeys. From Europe came wheat, horses, cattle, pigs, sugarcane — and devastating diseases.

New World crops transformed the Old World. The POTATO became Europe's most important food crop, feeding population booms. CORN fed Africa and Asia. TOMATOES became central to Italian cuisine (no tomatoes in Italy before 1500!). Meanwhile, HORSES transformed Indigenous life on the Great Plains, and WHEAT became a staple crop in the Americas. The global diet was permanently changed.

The darkest consequence: European diseases — smallpox, measles, influenza, typhus — devastated Indigenous populations who had no immunity. Historians estimate 50-90% of the Indigenous population of the Americas died within 100 years of contact. Entire civilizations collapsed. This was not intentional biological warfare (mostly), but it was the greatest demographic catastrophe in human history.

The Columbian Exchange also drove the transatlantic slave trade. European colonizers needed labor for sugar, tobacco, and cotton plantations. With Indigenous populations decimated by disease, they turned to enslaving Africans. Over 300 years, approximately 12.5 million Africans were forcibly transported to the Americas. The consequences of the Columbian Exchange were global, lasting, and deeply unequal.

slides.prompt: Analyze the Columbian Exchange: (1) On a world map, draw arrows showing at least 10 items exchanged between the Old and New Worlds. Color-code: green for plants, red for animals, blue for diseases, purple for ideas. (2) Create a T-chart: positive consequences and negative consequences of the Columbian Exchange. Include at least 5 of each. (3) Write a journal entry from ONE perspective: a European explorer, an Indigenous person encountering Europeans, or an African person forced into the slave trade. What would they experience? (4) Reflection: Can the Columbian Exchange be called 'progress'? Argue your position.

slides.text: The Columbian Exchange reminds us that historical events have winners and losers. The same process that brought potatoes to Europe brought smallpox to the Americas. Understanding multiple perspectives — European, Indigenous, African — is essential for honest history. We honor the past by acknowledging both its achievements and its injustices.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student identify major items in the Columbian Exchange, analyze both positive and negative consequences, consider multiple perspectives, and evaluate the exchange's lasting global impact?

parent_notes: This lesson deals with difficult topics: disease, colonization, and slavery. These are age-appropriate for upper elementary but may prompt emotional responses. Emphasize that understanding painful history helps prevent repeating it. The multiple-perspective approach is crucial — history looks very different depending on whose eyes you see it through. Ask your child: 'Whose perspective is usually centered in history books? Whose is often missing?'

title: Colonialism's Geographic Legacy — How Empires Shaped the Modern Map
description: Students examine how European colonialism reshaped global geography, from arbitrary borders to resource extraction patterns. They analyze colonial maps, trace lasting geographic impacts, and discuss how colonial legacies continue to affect nations today.
instructions:
1. Define colonialism: one country controlling another's territory and resources.
2. Map the major colonial empires: British, French, Spanish, Portuguese, Dutch, Belgian.
3. Discuss motivations: resources, markets, strategic locations, ideology.
4. Examine how colonial borders ignored existing ethnic and cultural boundaries.
5. Study resource extraction: how colonies supplied raw materials to Europe.
6. Analyze infrastructure: railroads and ports built to export resources, not serve locals.
7. Discuss decolonization: the wave of independence movements (1940s-1960s).
8. Trace colonial legacies in modern geography: languages, borders, economies.
9. Students create 'then and now' colonial maps.
10. Reflect: How do colonial decisions still affect people today?

slides.heading: Colonialism's Geographic Legacy
slides.subheading: How Empires Shaped the Modern Map

slides.setup_instructions: Print colonial empire maps at their peak (c. 1914) alongside modern political maps. Prepare decolonization timelines and resource extraction diagrams.

slides.text: By 1914, European powers controlled about 84% of the world's land surface. The BRITISH EMPIRE was the largest in history, spanning every continent. FRANCE controlled much of West and North Africa and Southeast Asia. SPAIN and PORTUGAL divided Latin America. BELGIUM controlled the Congo. The DUTCH held Indonesia. This was not voluntary — it was conquest, occupation, and exploitation.

Colonial borders were drawn in European capitals by people who had never visited the territories. The 1884 Berlin Conference divided Africa among European powers using straight lines on a map, splitting ethnic groups and combining rival ones. These borders persist today: 44% of Africa's borders are straight lines. The consequences include ethnic conflicts, civil wars, and political instability that continue into the present.

Colonial infrastructure tells the story of extraction. In many African and Asian countries, railroads run from mines and plantations to ports — not between cities. Roads connect resource areas to shipping points, not communities to each other. This infrastructure was built to move resources OUT of colonies, not to develop them. Many countries still struggle with this inherited geography of extraction.

Decolonization swept the globe after World War II. India gained independence in 1947. Most of Africa became independent in the 1960s. But independence did not erase colonial legacies: arbitrary borders remained, economic structures persisted, and former colonial languages (English, French, Portuguese) became official languages. Understanding colonialism's geographic legacy is essential for understanding today's world.

slides.prompt: Map colonialism's legacy: (1) On a blank world map, color-code regions by colonial power (c. 1914). Use a legend. What pattern do you notice? (2) Compare this colonial map with a modern political map. Identify 5 countries whose borders were drawn by colonial powers. (3) Research: Pick one former colony. What language is spoken? What are its main exports? Where do its railroads and roads go? How do these reflect colonial history? (4) Journal: Should former colonial powers bear responsibility for the challenges their former colonies face today? Argue your position with evidence.

slides.text: Colonial geography is not ancient history — it is the foundation of the modern world map. Understanding why borders exist where they do, why certain languages are spoken where they are, and why resources flow the way they do requires understanding colonialism. Geography shaped by power continues to affect billions of people every day.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student map major colonial empires, analyze how colonial decisions shaped borders and infrastructure, trace colonial legacies in modern geography, and evaluate the ongoing impact of colonialism?

parent_notes: Colonialism is a sensitive but essential topic. The geographic approach makes it concrete: borders on a map, railroads to ports, languages spoken. Help your child understand that colonialism was not just a historical event but a system whose effects persist. When they see news about conflicts in Africa or economic challenges in former colonies, the colonial context often provides crucial understanding. Encourage thoughtful discussion rather than simple blame.

title: Esperanza Rising by Pam Muñoz Ryan — Chapters 1–3: From Riches to Loss
description: Students begin reading Esperanza Rising, exploring Esperanza's privileged life on a Mexican ranch and the devastating events that force her family to flee to California. They analyze character, setting, and the themes of identity and social class.
instructions:
1. Introduce the novel: set in 1930s Mexico and California during the Great Depression.
2. Read chapters 1-3 aloud with expression.
3. Discuss Esperanza's life on El Rancho de las Rosas: wealth, privilege, family.
4. Analyze the tragedy that changes everything.
5. Discuss how Esperanza's identity is tied to her social position.
6. Explore the setting: 1930s Mexico, land ownership, class structure.
7. Connect to history: the Mexican Revolution's aftermath, the Great Depression.
8. Discuss the chapter title structure (named after fruits and vegetables).
9. Students write character analyses and predictions.
10. Vocabulary: campesinos, aguascalientes, el patrón, la cosecha.
materials_needed: Esperanza Rising by Pam Muñoz Ryan

items: Esperanza Rising by Pam Muñoz Ryan
slides.setup_instructions: Have copies of Esperanza Rising available. Prepare vocabulary cards for Spanish terms. Display a map showing Aguascalientes, Mexico, and the California farming region.

slides.text: Esperanza Rising is set during the Great Depression (1930s). Esperanza Ortega lives a privileged life on a vast ranch in Aguascalientes, Mexico. Her father is a wealthy landowner (el patrón). She has servants, beautiful clothes, and never worries about money. But tragedy strikes, and Esperanza must flee to California, where she becomes a migrant farm worker — the very people she once looked down upon.

The chapter titles are named after fruits and vegetables that mark the harvest seasons: grapes, figs, cantaloupes, onions, almonds, asparagus. This structure connects Esperanza's personal journey to the agricultural calendar and the lives of farm workers. As the seasons change, so does Esperanza — from a pampered child to a resilient young woman.

Pay attention to social class in these opening chapters. Esperanza's world has strict divisions: patrón (landowner) above campesinos (farm workers). She barely notices the workers on her own ranch. When her life changes, she must become one of them. This dramatic reversal forces her to question everything she believed about status and worth.

The novel draws from real history: after the Mexican Revolution (1910-1920), land ownership remained concentrated among the wealthy. Meanwhile, the Great Depression devastated economies worldwide. In California, Mexican and Mexican-American workers faced discrimination, poor conditions, and deportation. Esperanza's personal story unfolds against this larger historical backdrop.

slides.prompt: Respond to chapters 1-3: (1) Character analysis: Describe Esperanza at the start of the novel. What are her strengths? What are her blind spots? Use specific text evidence. (2) On a map, trace the route from Aguascalientes to the California farming region. What geographic features would Esperanza cross? (3) How does Esperanza's social class shape her worldview? Find two specific moments where her privilege is visible. (4) Prediction: How do you think Esperanza will change by the end of the novel? What challenges will force her to grow?

slides.text: Esperanza Rising challenges us to consider how social class shapes identity. Esperanza believes she IS her social position — a wealthy rancher's daughter. When that position is stripped away, she must discover who she really is. This question — Am I defined by my circumstances or by my character? — is one every person must answer.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student describe Esperanza's character and social position, identify how class shapes her worldview, connect the story to historical context, and make evidence-based predictions?

parent_notes: Esperanza Rising is a powerful novel about resilience, identity, and social justice. It deals with themes of class, immigration, and discrimination that are both historical and contemporary. The Spanish vocabulary throughout the book honors the characters' culture. If your family speaks Spanish, this is a wonderful opportunity to celebrate bilingualism. Discuss: Has your child ever had their assumptions about someone challenged? How does privilege shape what we see and do not see?

title: Research Paper Drafting — Writing Body Paragraphs with Evidence
description: Students draft body paragraphs for their research papers, practicing the integration of evidence from multiple sources. They learn to introduce quotes, paraphrase effectively, and analyze evidence to support their arguments.
instructions:
1. Review outlines from the previous lesson.
2. Model writing a body paragraph using the TEA structure.
3. Demonstrate introducing a quote: signal phrase + quote + citation.
4. Practice paraphrasing: restating ideas in your own words.
5. Distinguish quoting, paraphrasing, and summarizing.
6. Model analyzing evidence: explaining WHY it supports the topic sentence.
7. Practice writing transition sentences between paragraphs.
8. Students draft 2-3 body paragraphs from their outlines.
9. Peer review: Is the evidence well-integrated? Is the analysis clear?
10. Revise based on feedback.

slides.setup_instructions: Have students bring their outlines. Prepare TEA paragraph models and quote integration guides. Provide transition word lists.

slides.text: Each body paragraph follows the TEA pattern: TOPIC sentence states the paragraph's main idea. EVIDENCE supports it with facts, quotes, or data from your research. ANALYSIS explains why the evidence matters and how it connects to your thesis. Without analysis, evidence is just a fact floating in space.

Integrating quotes: Never drop a quote into your paragraph without introduction. Use a SIGNAL PHRASE: 'According to Dr. Martinez (2021), ...' or 'As the National Geographic report explains, ...' After the quote, ANALYZE it: What does this mean? Why does it matter? How does it support your argument?

PARAPHRASING means restating someone else's idea in YOUR words. It is not just changing a few words — you must restructure the sentence entirely. Original: 'Deforestation destroys habitats for 80% of terrestrial species.' Paraphrase: 'The clearing of forests eliminates living spaces for the vast majority of land-based animals and plants.' Still cite the source even when paraphrasing.

TRANSITIONS connect paragraphs and show relationships: 'Furthermore' (adding), 'However' (contrasting), 'As a result' (cause-effect), 'Similarly' (comparing). Strong transitions guide the reader through your argument. Without them, your paper feels like a list of disconnected paragraphs instead of a flowing argument.

slides.prompt: Draft your body paragraphs: (1) Using your outline, draft your first body paragraph following the TEA pattern. Include at least one piece of evidence with a signal phrase and citation. (2) Draft your second body paragraph with a different type of evidence (quote vs. paraphrase vs. statistic). (3) Write a transition sentence connecting paragraphs 1 and 2. (4) Draft your third body paragraph. (5) Peer review: Exchange drafts. Mark where evidence is well-integrated and where analysis could be stronger. Does each paragraph clearly support the thesis?

slides.text: Body paragraphs are the engine of your research paper. Each one makes a specific point, supports it with evidence, and explains why it matters. The TEA structure ensures you never present evidence without analysis. Strong writers do not just show facts — they explain what the facts mean.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student write body paragraphs following the TEA structure, integrate quotes with signal phrases, paraphrase effectively, use transitions, and analyze evidence in relation to the thesis?

parent_notes: The body paragraph is where many student writers struggle. They either present evidence without analysis (a 'data dump') or make claims without evidence. The TEA pattern prevents both. When reviewing your child's work, look for the analysis sentences — the 'so what?' that follows each piece of evidence. If they can explain why their evidence matters, they are thinking critically. Practice paraphrasing at home by having your child explain a news article in their own words.

title: Proportions — Solving with Cross-Multiplication
description: Students extend ratio understanding to proportions: equations stating that two ratios are equal. They learn to identify proportional relationships, use cross-multiplication to solve for unknowns, and apply proportions to scale drawings, maps, and real-world problems.
instructions:
1. Define proportion: two equal ratios (a/b = c/d).
2. Demonstrate how to check if two ratios form a proportion.
3. Introduce cross-multiplication: a x d = b x c.
4. Solve proportions for unknown values using cross-multiplication.
5. Apply proportions to scale drawings.
6. Apply proportions to map reading.
7. Solve real-world proportion problems: similar figures, unit pricing.
8. Connect proportions to fractions and equivalent fractions.
9. Students solve a variety of proportion problems.
10. Reflect: How are proportions used in everyday life?

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare cross-multiplication guides and scale drawing examples. Provide maps with distance scales for practice problems.

slides.text: A PROPORTION states that two ratios are equal: 3/4 = 6/8. To check, cross-multiply: 3 x 8 = 24 and 4 x 6 = 24. Equal? Then it is a proportion. Not equal? Then it is not. Cross-multiplication converts a ratio comparison into simple multiplication, making proportions easy to verify and solve.

Solving for unknowns: If 3/5 = x/20, cross-multiply: 3 x 20 = 5 x x. So 60 = 5x. Divide both sides by 5: x = 12. This method works for any proportion with one unknown. Set up the proportion with the unknown, cross-multiply, then solve the resulting equation.

Scale drawings use proportions: if a blueprint has a scale of 1 inch = 4 feet, and a room measures 3.5 inches on the blueprint, the actual room is 3.5 x 4 = 14 feet. Set it up as a proportion: 1/4 = 3.5/x. Cross-multiply: 1 x x = 4 x 3.5. x = 14 feet. Maps work the same way.

Proportional thinking is everywhere: If 3 apples cost $2.49, how much do 7 apples cost? Set up: 3/2.49 = 7/x. Cross-multiply: 3x = 7 x 2.49 = 17.43. x = $5.81. SIMILAR FIGURES have proportional sides: if a triangle has sides 3, 4, 5 and a similar triangle has its shortest side as 9, then the sides are 9, 12, 15 (each multiplied by 3).

slides.prompt: Proportion practice: (1) Determine if these are proportions: 4/6 and 10/15; 3/8 and 9/20; 5/7 and 15/21. (2) Solve: x/12 = 5/8; 7/x = 21/36; 4/9 = 16/x. (3) A map scale is 1 cm = 25 km. Two cities are 8.4 cm apart on the map. How far apart are they in reality? (4) A model car is 1/24 scale. If the real car is 180 inches long, how long is the model? (5) A recipe serves 6 people using 4 cups of flour. How many cups for 15 people?

slides.text: Proportions connect mathematics to the real world: maps, blueprints, recipes, shopping, and science all use proportional reasoning. Cross-multiplication gives you a reliable method for solving any proportion. When you see two quantities that scale together, you are looking at a proportion.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student identify proportional relationships, use cross-multiplication to solve proportions, apply proportions to scale drawings and maps, and solve real-world proportion problems?

parent_notes: Proportions are one of the most universally useful math concepts. They appear in cooking, shopping, construction, art, and science. Practice at home: have your child calculate unit prices at the grocery store, measure rooms and create scale drawings, or double/halve recipes. The cross-multiplication method is a powerful tool, but make sure your child also understands WHY it works (equal ratios means the cross products are equal). Understanding builds stronger problem-solving than memorizing a procedure.

title: Chemical Reactions Continued — Types and Balancing Equations
description: Students explore different types of chemical reactions including synthesis, decomposition, and combustion. They learn to read and balance simple chemical equations and conduct safe kitchen-chemistry experiments demonstrating each reaction type.
instructions:
1. Review chemical reactions: reactants transform into products.
2. Introduce reaction types: synthesis (A+B→AB), decomposition (AB→A+B), combustion.
3. Provide everyday examples of each type.
4. Introduce chemical equations: symbols and formulas.
5. Explain the Law of Conservation of Mass: atoms are rearranged, not created or destroyed.
6. Demonstrate simple equation balancing.
7. Practice balancing equations with manipulatives.
8. Conduct safe experiments: baking soda + vinegar, hydrogen peroxide decomposition.
9. Students identify reaction types in experiments.
10. Connect to real life: cooking, rusting, digestion as chemical reactions.

slides.setup_instructions: Set up experiment stations with safety goggles and trays for spills. Prepare atom manipulatives for equation balancing. Pre-measure baking soda and vinegar portions.

slides.text: Chemical reactions fall into categories: SYNTHESIS — two or more substances combine to form one new substance (A + B → AB). Iron + oxygen → iron oxide (rust). DECOMPOSITION — one substance breaks into two or more simpler substances (AB → A + B). Water → hydrogen + oxygen (with electricity). COMBUSTION — a substance reacts with oxygen, releasing energy (heat and light). Wood + oxygen → carbon dioxide + water + energy.

Chemical equations are shorthand for reactions. Reactants (starting materials) are on the left, products (results) on the right, connected by an arrow. H2 + O2 → H2O means hydrogen gas plus oxygen gas produces water. But this equation is NOT balanced: 2 oxygen atoms on the left but only 1 on the right.

The Law of Conservation of Mass says atoms cannot be created or destroyed in a chemical reaction — only rearranged. So equations must BALANCE: the same number of each type of atom on both sides. 2H2 + O2 → 2H2O is balanced: 4 hydrogen atoms and 2 oxygen atoms on each side. Balancing equations is like solving a puzzle.

Kitchen chemistry demonstrates reactions safely. Baking soda (NaHCO3) + vinegar (CH3COOH) is an ACID-BASE reaction producing carbon dioxide gas (the bubbles). Hydrogen peroxide decomposes into water and oxygen (yeast acts as a catalyst to speed it up). Cooking an egg is a reaction where heat changes protein structure permanently. Chemistry is not just lab science — it is everywhere.

slides.prompt: Chemistry experiments: (1) Mix baking soda and vinegar. Observe: What do you see? What type of reaction is this? What gas is produced? Record observations. (2) Add yeast to hydrogen peroxide with a drop of dish soap. What happens? This is decomposition — what are the products? (3) Practice balancing: H2 + Cl2 → HCl; Fe + O2 → Fe2O3; CH4 + O2 → CO2 + H2O. Use manipulatives to count atoms on each side. (4) List 5 chemical reactions you encounter daily (cooking, cleaning, digestion, rusting, burning). Classify each by type.

slides.text: Chemical reactions are the engine of the universe. Stars burn through fusion, your body runs on biochemical reactions, and technology depends on controlled chemistry. Understanding reaction types and balanced equations gives you a framework for understanding the transformations happening all around you, all the time.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student classify reactions by type, explain the Law of Conservation of Mass, balance simple chemical equations, and identify chemical reactions in everyday life?

parent_notes: The hands-on experiments make chemistry tangible and exciting. All materials used are safe household items, but supervision is important. The baking soda and vinegar reaction is a classic because it is dramatic (bubbling and fizzing) yet perfectly safe. The equation balancing introduces algebraic thinking in a scientific context. Encourage curiosity: when your child sees cooking, cleaning, or rusting, ask 'What type of chemical reaction is happening?'

title: Music of the Age of Exploration — Sea Shanties, Court Music, and Cultural Exchange
description: Students explore music from the Age of Exploration, including European court music, sea shanties sung by sailors, and the beginnings of musical exchange between cultures. They learn how exploration spread musical traditions across the globe.
instructions:
1. Set historical context: the Age of Exploration (1400s-1600s).
2. Listen to European court music: lute songs, dance music.
3. Introduce sea shanties: work songs that coordinated sailors' tasks.
4. Listen to and analyze a sea shanty: rhythm, call-and-response structure.
5. Discuss the function of work songs in general.
6. Explore how exploration led to musical exchange between cultures.
7. Listen to examples of musical fusion from colonial encounters.
8. Discuss how instruments traveled: the guitar's journey from Middle East to Spain to Americas.
9. Students learn and sing a simple sea shanty.
10. Reflect: How does music travel and change across cultures?
